Award.AwardTitle: GEM: Dipolarization Fronts and Reconnection Onset in Realistic Models of the Magnetotail
Award.AbstractNarration:
The magnetosphere is very dynamic. Magnetospheric substorms occur every few hours. Viewed from the Earth they are visible as auroral displays. In space one of the main phenomena associated with magnetospheric substorms is the generation of dipolarization fronts. These are rapid increases in the component of the magnetic field normal to the plasma sheet that propagate from the magnetotail toward the Earth. They are called dipolarization fronts (DFs) since the magnetic field assumes a more "dipole like" configuration. The most common explanation for DFs is that they are related to magnetic reconnection. This work is relevant to other studies of current sheets such as those in planetary magnetospheres, the solor corona and the solar wind.

The goal of this proposal is to investigate the formation of DFs in realistic tail models. The team proposes to construct new classes of self-consistent 2D current sheet equilibria similar to those observed during the growth phase of substorms. They will investigate their stability to reconnection by using kinetic theory and 2D particle in cell (PIC) simulations with realistic electron to ion mass ratio. This will be extended to 3D PIC simulations to investigate the whole spectrum of tail plasma responses including tearing, ballooning/interchange and flapping motions. The kinetic picture will be compared with that from global magnetohydrodynamic models with the goal of including the kinetic physics in the global models.

The Applied Physics Laboratory has a program for summer students to help with the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Charged particles, electrons and ions forming space plasmas usually drift in the ambient magnetic field making plasmas frozen in that field. The frozen-in condition may be broken when oppositely directed field lines approach each other so closely that particles become unmagnetized and their orbits become different from conventional drift motions. As a result, magnetic field lines may change their connectivity near so-called X-lines in the process of magnetic reconnection. This process was introduced to explain major sources of space weather disturbances on the Sun, solar flares and coronal mass ejections It was also invoked to describe the structure of the Earth's magnetosphere, the plasma bubble surrounding our planet and protecting its life from the hazardous stream of high-energy particles emitted by our star. Finally, to explain a delayed explosive response of the polar regions of the magnetosphere to solar wind disturbances during substorms, it was proposed that the substorm explosions are powered by the unsteady reconnection in the tail due to the formation of another "near-Earth" X-line.

One of the major discoveries provided by recent multi-probe missions Cluster and THEMIS has become the finding of dipolarization fronts, shock-like structures that provide the main energy and magnetic flux transfer in unsteady magnetotail reconnection. Fronts were also found in kinetic simulations of magnetotail plasmas. However, it remained unclear if they are formed as reconnection exhausts after the formation of the electron-scale current sheet, or they form spontaneously from the regions of accumulated flux, or they form as a result of non-reconnection instabilities caused by magnetic buoyancy of the pre-onset magnetotail configurations.

In this project, we combined kinetic particle-in-cell (PIC) and magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations of the tail with the reconstruction of its structure and dynamics during substorms from data. The latter was made using modern data-mining (DM) algorithms. It was shown that the DM approach helps resolve the formation of new X-lines in the tail (Fig. 1). It was also shown that some substorms are indeed preceded by the formation of the flux accumulation regions, prone to both spontaneous front formation and buoyancy-driven instabilities. These findings were confirmed by PIC and MHD simulations (Fig. 2). Finally, it was found that the original scenario, when the tail current sheet is squeezed till the formation of the electron-scale current, X-line formation and ejection of fronts from it is also possible, but it likely takes place farther in the tail.

The obtained results help understand the mechanisms of the reconnection onset and front formation in the magnetotail. They can be directly utilized in global MHD simulations of the magnetosphere to describe kinetic ion-scale current sheets and their disruption causing reconnection and front formation, the processes that cannot be reproduced by ideal MHD models. They can also be used to describe similar processes in the solar corona and other astrophysical plasmas.
